entry.title: Experience at SAP CodeJam Kolkata 2025 || 4th March & 5th March, 2025
entry.content:
Reflecting on SAP CodeJam 2025 - Kolkata 


Iâ€™m thrilled to share my experience attending the SAP CodeJam 2025 in Kolkata, driven by SAP Developer advocates @noravonthenen , @Vitaliy-R , @sheenamk  and @eshrinivasan  hosted by Capgemini this year! The session centered around Machine Learning (ML) with Python and Generative AI (GenAI) in SAP, and it was an eye-opener into how these groundbreaking technologies are shaping the future of enterprise solutions.

Some key insights that stood out:

ğŸ¤– Empowering SAP Consultants with Real-Time AI: We discussed how GenAI and ML can help SAP consultants tackle real-time challenges. AI is enhancing efficiency and reducing the time spent on manual interventions. This is a game-changer in real-time project scenarios!

ğŸ“Š Predictive Analytics for Smarter Decisions: With ML models embedded in SAP for smarter decision-making, such as optimizing processes, forecasting demand, and identifying risksâ€”leading to more proactive, data-driven strategies.

âš¡ Real-Time Problem Solving: GenAI tools are revolutionizing issue resolution during SAP implementations. By offering automated, instant troubleshooting, consultants can focus on high-value strategic decisions rather than spending time on repetitive system fixes.

ğŸ”§ Tailored Solutions at Speed: The ability of GenAI to generate custom code, configurations, and solutions in real-time allows SAP consultants to swiftly address client needs, significantly reducing implementation times while delivering highly personalized, impactful outcomes.

Here are some use cases and benefits of GenAI and ML with Python in SAP:

Use Cases:

  1. Predictive Analytics:

    • Use Case: Use ML models to forecast demand, optimize inventory, and predict financial trends in SAP.
    • Benefit: Helps businesses make data-driven decisions, reduce costs, and improve forecasting accuracy.

  2. Process Automation (RPA):

    • Use Case: Automate repetitive tasks like data entry, report generation, or invoice processing using Python scripts and GenAI.
    • Benefit: Reduces manual labor, minimizes errors, and accelerates process completion.

  3. Customer Insights and Personalization:

    • Use Case: Leverage ML to analyze customer behavior data and create personalized product recommendations in SAP.
    • Benefit: Improves customer satisfaction and drives sales by delivering more tailored experiences.

  4. Anomaly Detection:

    • Use Case: Detect outliers or unusual transactions in financial or inventory data using ML models trained in Python.
    • Benefit: Identifies potential fraud or errors quickly, enhancing security and data integrity.

  5. Automated Reporting and Dashboards:

    • Use Case: Use GenAI to generate custom reports and dashboards based on business parameters in SAP.
    • Benefit: Provides real-time insights without manual report creation, improving decision-making speed.

  6. Supply Chain Optimization:

    • Use Case: Use ML algorithms to optimize supply chain processes in SAP, from procurement to delivery.
    • Benefit: Reduces operational costs, minimizes delays, and enhances inventory management.

Benefits:

  1. Enhanced Efficiency:

    • Automates repetitive tasks, reducing manual effort and increasing overall system efficiency.

  2. Improved Accuracy:

    • ML models enhance decision-making accuracy by providing data-driven insights and predictions.

  3. Cost Savings:

    • Reduces costs by improving forecasting, streamlining processes, and identifying inefficiencies.

  4. Scalability:

    • Python and AI-powered models can scale to meet the growing data needs of businesses, ensuring systems can handle increased complexity over time.

  5. Faster Decision-Making:

    • Real-time insights from GenAI and ML lead to quicker and more informed decisions.

By integrating Python, GenAI, and ML into SAP, businesses can unlock automation, predictive capabilities, and smarter analytics, driving significant business value.

Apart from these, many key-points are taken away i.e. types of ML ( Supervised, Unsupervised, Reinforcement Learning ), Training a data model, Business Data Cloud, Data Preparation, Feature Engineering, Data Frame, EDA etc. from @Vitaliy-R on 4th March, Getting Started with Machine Learning using SAP HANA. Again on 5th March, Getting Started with Generative AI Hub on SAP AI Core session by @noravonthenen key-points ( AI Buzzwords )are taken away i.e. Fine Tuning, Orchestration including Grounding, Prompt Templating, Content Filter, Data Masking, LLM Access and all the hands-on procedure i.e. define Orchestration service deployment, AI model deployment etc.

Kudos to Chatrath Harinder Singh, @Sharmistha22 , Goutam Dasgupta, Abhishek Guha Roy for helping to make this event successful.

Also thank you @DataTherapist for believing in me to make this event a success. Also, thank you @Raya_16 and @TanushreeD  to make this event in Capgemini.

entry.title: Document Information Extraction â€“ Q1 2025 Highlights
entry.content:
Find out whatâ€™s new in the Document Information Extraction service.

 

New Excel, Email and Text File Formats

Document Information Extraction, premium edition now supports new Excel, email, and text file types, such as CSV, XLSX, XLSM, DOCX, EMLX, MSG, PAGES, RTF, and TXT. See the complete list sorted by document types in Supported File Types (Premium Edition).

 

New Invoice Header Fields

You can now extract a more comprehensive list of address-related header fields from invoice documents. The list includes Buyer City, Supplier City, Buyer Country Code, and Supplier Country Code. See all of the standard header fields supported by Document Information Extraction in Extracted Header Fields.

 

Decommissioning and Deprecation

As announced in May 2024, the Enrichment Data API Endpoint: Delete Enrichment Data (Synchronous) (DELETE /data) has been decommissioned and is no longer available. Please use the endpoint Delete Enrichment Data (Asynchronous) (DELETE /data/jobs) to delete data records. For more information, check out Delete Enrichment Data (Synchronous) - Decommissioned | SAP Help Portal and Delete Enrichment Data (Asynchronous) | SAP Help Portal.

The Document API endpoint Get Request Payload (GET /document/jobs/{id}/request) is now deprecated and is scheduled for decommissioning in September 2025. Following that date, the endpoint will no longer be available. Find more details in the blog post: Document Information Extraction â€“ Deprecation of D... - SAP Community.

 

Support for the Identity Authentication Service

As of January 2025, you can subscribe to the Document Information Extraction UI using the Identity Authentication service to handle authentication and authorization tasks in SAP BTP. Find all the details in Subscribing to the Document Information Extraction UI With the Identity Authentication Service.

 

Instant Learning  

If youâ€™ve activated instant learning in Document Information Extraction, premium edition, the service can now use your feedback to select the best model for individual fields in SAP schemas for the standard document types: invoice, payment advice, and purchase order. For more information, see Instant Learning (Premium Edition) and Instant Learning (Premium Edition): Best Practices.

 

Export and Import Feature for Instant Learning

You can now export and import documents that you've edited and confirmed for use with instant learning. This new feature of the Document Information Extraction UI allows you to quickly and easily export documents along with all information relevant for instant learning and import them for use in another context. Seeâ€¯Export/Import Documents. 

You can also export documents and associated information, such as ground truth and related instant learning data, via the new Document API endpoint Export Document Details.

 

More Meaningful Extraction Confidence Ranges

Document Information Extraction, premium edition now provides more meaningful extraction confidence ranges for fields with the setup type auto and no default extractor â€“ before you enter any feedback on results. The service does so by checking whether the data type of the extracted information matches the data type for the respective field in the schema.

 

Stay up to date with all the latest developments for Document Information Extraction â€“ by following the tag #DocumentInformationExtraction.

entry.title: Leveraging AI-Driven Test Automation for SAP Commerce Cloud Optimization
entry.content:
Why SAP Commerce Cloud Testing?

With the growing adoption of SAP Commerce Cloud for e-commerce, maintaining system performance and reliability has become critical. Due to the platformâ€™s complexityâ€”frequent updates, integrations, and diverse user requirementsâ€”SAP Commerce Cloud testing becomes increasingly critical.

With SAP Commerce Cloud's numerous integrations, thorough testing is needed to guarantee seamless functionality across all components. And, as e-commerce operations scale, the demand for continuous, efficient testing grows bigger still.

Consequently, manual testing is no longer sufficient to keep pace with these evolving demands. However, AI-driven SAP Commerce Cloud testing offers a solution. By leveraging AI, businesses can optimize platform performance, reduce time-to-market, and enhance overall reliability while ensuring a high-quality user experience.

The Challenges of SAP Commerce Cloud Testing

Traditional testing methods often fall short when it comes to handling the scale, complexity, and rapid changes associated with SAP Commerce Cloud environments. Some of the most prevalent challenges are:

High Volume of Transactions: E-commerce platforms handle a massive volume of transactions, making manual or conventional testing impractical.

Frequent Updates: Regular updates, customizations, and feature enhancements in the SAP Commerce Cloud demand frequent testing to ensure zero disruptions to services.

Complex Integrations: SAP Commerce Cloud integrates with numerous third-party systems like payment gateways, CRM tools, and inventory management systems, which increases testing complexity.

User Experience: Ensuring a consistent and bug-free user experience across a wide range of devices, browsers, and networks requires thorough testing at scale.

Regression Testing: With the constant deployment of new features, regression testing is necessary to ensure that updates do not break existing functionalities.

These challenges require a robust, scalable, and efficient testing solution capable of adapting to the evolving needs of modern e-commerce platforms.

Enter AI-Driven Test Automation

AI is revolutionizing how organizations approach testing, offering new opportunities for optimizing SAP Commerce Cloud environments. AI-driven test automation leverages machine learning, natural language processing (NLP), and other advanced algorithms to significantly improve the efficiency and accuracy of testing processes. Unlike traditional methods, which rely on predefined scripts and manual intervention, AI-based testing solutions can autonomously identify issues, predict potential failure points, and adapt to new changes in real time.

How AI-Driven Test Automation Works

AI-powered test automation for SAP Commerce Cloud works through several key features that make it highly effective:

Intelligent Test Generation: AI tools have the capability to autonomously create test cases by analyzing application behavior and leveraging historical testing data. By analyzing past test outcomes and learning from them, AI systems can create tests that cover a broader range of scenarios, including edge cases that might otherwise be missed.

Dynamic Test Maintenance: As SAP Commerce Cloud environments evolve, traditional test scripts often require manual updates. AI-driven solutions can autonomously update tests when the application undergoes changes or when new features are introduced, reducing the overhead of test maintenance.

Enhanced Test Coverage: AI-powered testing can automatically detect gaps in test coverage by analyzing the system architecture and usage patterns. This ensures that all critical functionalities are tested, regardless of how frequently the platform changes.

Regression Testing: One of the most time-consuming aspects of testing is regression testing, which ensures that new changes do not negatively impact existing functionality. AI-based automation tools can intelligently prioritize regression tests based on the likelihood of change, focusing resources on areas of the application most at risk of failure.

Faster Execution and Feedback: AI-driven test automation tools are capable of executing tests at a significantly faster rate than manual testing. This speed is crucial for organizations looking to deploy frequent updates or rapidly respond to customer feedback.

Predictive Analytics: AI solutions can predict areas of the SAP Commerce Cloud platform that are most likely to fail or require attention, based on historical test data. This proactive strategy allows businesses to address potential issues before they affect users.

Key Benefits of AI-Driven Test Automation for SAP Commerce Cloud Optimization

The integration of AI into SAP Commerce Cloud testing offers several compelling benefits that directly contribute to platform optimization:

1. Faster Time-to-Market

AI-driven test automation accelerates the testing process, allowing businesses to deploy new features and updates faster. This is crucial in an e-commerce landscape where speed and agility are key differentiators. By reducing the time spent on manual testing and troubleshooting, organizations can roll out innovations quicker, gaining a competitive edge.

2. Cost Savings

Although the upfront cost of AI-driven testing tools may appear high, the long-term savings are considerable. By automating repetitive and time-consuming tasks, businesses can reduce the need for manual testing resources. Furthermore, the reduced risk of bugs or system failures means fewer emergency fixes, leading to lower operational costs.

3. Improved Test Accuracy

AI systems learn from past tests and continuously improve their testing strategies, leading to more accurate and comprehensive testing. This reduces the likelihood of bugs slipping through the cracks and ensures that any issues are caught early in the development cycle.

4. Scalability

As businesses scale their SAP Commerce Cloud environments to handle higher volumes of traffic and transactions, AI-driven testing can easily adapt to the increased complexity. These tools are designed to scale with the platform, ensuring consistent performance testing regardless of the size of the e-commerce operation.

5. Seamless Integration with CI/CD Pipelines

AI-based test automation tools integrate seamlessly with CI/CD pipelines, allowing businesses to implement automated testing at every stage of the software development lifecycle. This ensures that testing becomes a seamless part of the development process, reducing bottlenecks and improving overall workflow efficiency.

6. Enhanced User Experience

Ultimately, the goal of testing is to deliver a flawless user experience. By using AI to identify issues early and test across a wide range of devices and platforms, businesses can ensure that customers enjoy a smooth, bug-free experience across all touchpoints.

Real-World Applications of AI-Driven Test Automation in SAP Commerce Cloud

Leading organizations are already leveraging AI-driven test automation to optimize their SAP Commerce Cloud platforms. For example, companies in the retail and manufacturing sectors have deployed AI-based testing tools to streamline the testing of customer-facing websites, ensuring a seamless shopping experience across multiple channels. Similarly, organizations in the financial services industry are using AI-driven testing to validate integrations with back-end systems, such as payment processors and CRM tools, ensuring that all parts of the SAP Commerce Cloud ecosystem work together without issues.

In addition, AI-based solutions can help improve accessibility testing for customers with disabilities, ensuring compliance with legal requirements and enhancing the overall customer experience.

Conclusion

The adoption of SAP Commerce Cloud provides businesses with powerful tools to enhance their e-commerce operations, but ensuring optimal performance across complex environments requires robust and efficient testing strategies. AI-driven test automation offers a cutting-edge solution for overcoming the challenges of traditional testing methods, enabling organizations to accelerate their time-to-market, reduce costs, and deliver a superior user experience.

By leveraging AI to automate and optimize the testing process, businesses can ensure that their SAP Commerce Cloud platforms remain reliable, scalable, and capable of meeting the demands of modern consumers. With continuous advancements in AI and machine learning, the future of SAP Commerce Cloud testing is not just about detecting errors but predicting and preventing themâ€”leading to more innovative and successful e-commerce solutions.

entry.title: Invoice Validation with SAP Document Information Extraction API & Python
entry.content:
Invoices are essential, but validating them manually can be tedious and error-prone. In this blog post, weâ€™ll walk through a Python-based workflow that leverages SAPâ€™s Document Information Extraction (DOX) API to extract invoice data and intelligently compare it against field records. The goal? Validate invoices and highlight discrepanciesâ€”all in one go.

Supported document types for the SAP Document Information Extraction Service include supplier invoice, purchase order, payment advice, and business cards. More to come in the roadmap.

This blog post builds on an excellent introductory guide by Joni â€“ here â€“ which covers getting started with SAP DOX API and testing it via Swagger. Here, we introduce Python logic, with Python modelling doing the heavy lifting of:

  • OCR-based document post and extraction (via SAP DOX API)
  • Confidence scoring and validation of key fields
  • Automatic detection and reporting of mismatches

TL;DR: Automate invoice data extraction and validation using SAP DOX API and Python. OCR your PDFs, validate against expected fields with confidence scoring, and flag mismatchesâ€”all in one streamlined Python pipeline.

This guide is for: SAP BTP developers, automation engineers, finance teams exploring DOX integration, or anyone dealing with high-volume invoice processing.

Step 1: Authentication with SAP BTP

First, we authenticate against SAP BTP using OAuth 2.0 to retrieve an access token.
Update <TENANT> to your SAP BTP tenant name.

The Bearer Token is required for all subsequent API calls to the DOX endpoint.

import requests
import json
 
client_id = ""
client_secret = ""
oauth_url = "https://<TENANT>.authentication.ap10.hana.ondemand.com/oauth/token?grant_type=client_credentials"
 
# Get access token
def get_access_token():
    token_response = requests.post(
        oauth_url,
        data={
            "grant_type": "client_credentials",
            "client_id": client_id,
            "client_secret": client_secret,
        },
        headers={
            "Content-Type": "application/x-www-form-urlencoded"
        }
    )
    
    if token_response.status_code == 200:
        return token_response.json().get("access_token")
    else:
        raise Exception(f"Failed to get token: {token_response.status_code} - {token_response.text}")

Step 2: Submitting an Invoice PDF for Document Information Extraction

Next, we upload a sample invoice PDF (in this case, Thai_Invoice_with_TH_date.pdf) to the DOX API. The POST/document/jobs endpoint performs a document submission (e.g a pdf, png or jpeg file) for asynchronous processing. If successful, the API returns a job ID which we use to track and fetch the results. This ID can be used with other endpoints, including GET/document/jobs/{id} and DELETE/document/jobs/{id}.

Sample Invoice:

import requests

url = "https://<TENANT>.ap10.doc.cloud.sap/document-information-extraction/v1/document/jobs"
access_token = get_access_token()
file_path = "Thai_Invoice_with_TH_date.pdf"

headers = {
    "Authorization": f"Bearer {access_token}",
    "accept": "application/json"
}

# simulate -F flags in curl
files = {
    'file': (file_path, open(file_path, 'rb'), 'application/pdf'),
    'options': (
        None,
        '''{
            "schemaName": "SAP_invoice_schema",
            "clientId": "c_00",
            "documentType": "invoice",
            "receivedDate": "2020-02-17",
            "enrichment": {
                "sender": {
                    "top": 5,
                    "type": "businessEntity",
                    "subtype": "supplier"
                }
            }
        }''',
        'application/json'
    )
}

response = requests.post(url, headers=headers, files=files)

if response.status_code in [200, 201]:
    print("Document submitted successfully!")
    print("ID:", response.json().get("id"))
else:
    print("Submission failed")
    print("Status Code:", response.status_code)
    print("Response:", response.text)

Step 3: Retrieving Extracted Data

Using the job ID, we retrieve the results. Replace {id} with the ID in the previous output. From the SAP Document Information Extraction interface, youâ€™ll also see your extracted fields formatted.

The extracted fields (like receiver address, receiver name, document date, and net amount) are returned with confidence scores, allowing us to evaluate the reliability of each extracted field.

You get the actual confidence scores via the DOX API instead of an extraction confidence range on the interface.

url = f"https://<TENANT>.ap10.doc.cloud.sap/document-information-
extraction/v1/document/jobs/{ID}"
response = requests.get(url, headers=headers)

if response.status_code == 200:
    data = response.json()
    fields = data.get("extraction", {}).get("headerFields", [])

    if not fields:
        print("No header fields extracted.")
    else:
        print("Extracted Fields:")
        for field in fields:
            print(f"- {field['name']}: {field['value']} (confidence: {round(field['confidence'], 2)})")
else:
    print("Failed to retrieve job data")
    print("Status:", response.status_code)
    print("Response:", response.text)

Step 4: Document Confidence Scoring and Mandatory Field Check

We define a list of mandatory fields and set a minimum confidence threshold (e.g., 70%).

The Document Confidence Score is reflected at the end of the output after checking for matching and missing fields.

min_confidence = 0.7  # threshold to flag low-match fields

mandatory_fields = {
    "receiverName": "Buyer Name",
    "receiverAddress": "Buyer Address",
    "documentDate": "Date Issued",
    "documentNumber": "Invoice Number",
    "currencyCode": "Currency",
    "taxAmount": "VAT Value",
    "senderAddress": "Company Address",
    "senderName": "Company Name",
    "taxId": "Tax ID"
}

if response.status_code == 200:
    data = response.json()
    fields = data.get("extraction", {}).get("headerFields", [])
    
    # Convert extracted fields into a dictionary: name => field
    extracted = {f["name"]: f for f in fields}
    
    total_score = 0
    max_score = len(mandatory_fields)
    low_match_flags = []

    print("Mandatory Field Check:\n")

    for key, label in mandatory_fields.items():
        field = extracted.get(key)
        if field:
            total_score += 1  # Presence of field
            print(f"{label} ({key}): {field['value']}") 
        else:
            print(f"{label} ({key}): MISSING")

    print("\nResult Summary:")
    print(f"Fields Found: {total_score}/{max_score}")
    
    if total_score < max_score:
        print("\nLow Match Fields:")
        # Check for missing fields and flag low match
        for key, label in mandatory_fields.items():
            if key not in extracted:
                print(f" - {label} ({key})")

    document_confidence_score = round((total_score / max_score) * 100, 2)
    print(f"\nDocument Confidence Score: {document_confidence_score}%")

else:
    print("Failed to fetch job results.")
    print(f"Status Code: {response.status_code}")
    print(f"Response: {response.text}")

Future Expansion

For integration and tracking â€“ youâ€™ll want your enterprise system as part of the Document Information Extraction process. While keeping all validation logic in Python, you can expand the case with fuzzy matching, error handling, and real databases, including SAP S/4HANA or SAP Build Process Automation:

  1. Pull real data dynamically
  2. Push results (e.g. approved/rejected invoices)
  3. Trigger workflows (emails, dashboards, auto-approval/review flagging etc.)
  4. Store validated invoice results in your backend
  5. Log confidence scores, mismatches, timestamps

All in all, this blog post provides a preliminary look into:

  • Invoice document posting and extraction with the SAP DOX API
  • Invoice validation
  • Confidence scoring

If you process high volumes of invoices, SAP Document Information Extraction can help you save countless hours and reduce errors.

If AI has to do something like instructing a robot about recognizing fruits

So ML is kind of like demonstrating the robot pictures of apples, bananas, and oranges â€” and letting it learn what each of them looks like, instead of explaining to it all the rules

Introduction of AI and ML in SAP

SAP S/4HANA, the cutting-edge ERP suite, is transforming the way businesses operate by incorporating advanced technologies like Artificial Intelligence (AI) and Machine Learning (ML). These innovations boost automation, refine decision-making, and maintain data integrity across a variety of industries. In this blog, weâ€™ll dive into how AI and ML are woven into SAP S/4HANA and explore their practical applications in the real world. 

Artificial Intelligence (AI) & Machine Learning (ML) in SAP S/4HANA

SAP S/4HANA leverages AI and ML to automate processes, reduce manual work, and provide predictive insights. Below are some key functionalities:

Sales & Customer Experience

  1. Automated Sales Order Processing: AI-powered chatbots process customer inquiries and create sales orders automatically, improving response times.

2. Leverage Joule

Joule is capable of creating sales orders in both the SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition and the Public Edition. Itâ€™s also a handy tool for managing various aspects of sales orders, including: -

  • Creating sales orders based on other documents: Joule can generate new sales orders by referencing existing sales orders, quotes, or contracts.
  • Generating sales order requests: It can assist users in crafting sales order requests by pulling information from unstructured data like PDFs or images.
  • Modifying sales order fields: Users can easily update fields at both the header and item levels with Joule.
  • Addressing sales order fulfilment issues: Itâ€™s equipped to help users tackle any problems related to fulfilling sales orders.
  • Navigating to relevant apps: Joule can direct users to specific applications within SAP S/4HANA Cloud, such as the "Track Sales Orders" app.
  • Retrieving sales order information: It can deliver summaries and detailed insights about sales orders, including document flow and pricing condition

 3. AI-Based Sales Order Autocompletion:

Functionality: SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition offers AI-driven autocompletion, which uses historical data and machine learning to provide intelligent recommendations for completing sales order data. 

Example: The system can suggest the correct shipping address, payment terms, or material details based on past orders with similar characteristics. 

SAP Fiori App: The "Monitor Recommendations for Sales Document Completion" app provides a central entry point to view incomplete sales orders and corresponding data field recommendations. 

4. Importing Sales Orders from Excel Spreadsheets:

Functionality: You can use the SAP Fiori app "Import Sales Orders" to batch-create sales orders directly from Excel files. 

Process:

    • Upload the Excel file containing the sales order data. 
    • The system automatically creates sales order requests and populates the data. 
    • You can then simulate or create the sales order. 

SAP BTP Use Case:  SAP Business Technology Platform (BTP) can be used to automate sales order creation from Excel files, leveraging robotic process automation (RPA) to extract data from Excel and create sales order documents in SAP S/4HANA. 

5. Automating Sales Order Creation from Unstructured Data:

Functionality: You can use SAP Build Process Automation to create an RPA bot to automate the processing of sales order requests received in the form of unstructured files like PDFs, images, etc

 

 Process:

    • The bot scans emails for keywords in the subject line. 
    • It extracts attachments from the emails and uploads them to the "Create Sales Orders - Automatic Extraction" app. 
    • The app creates sales order requests and uploads the email attachments to a document information extraction service. 
    • The service extracts relevant information from the email attachments. 

6. SAP Sales Cloud Version 2, duplicate detection

Sales agents can leverage the feature that performs a check, comparing the configured fields with the list of existing accounts within the system. As an administrator, they can configure the duplicate check for accounts. Once configured, any new account that is created is checked against the configured fields and the result displays a list of the existing accounts with a confidence score, which enables sales agents to take a decision whether or not to proceed with the account creation.

Benefits

    • Prevent from creating more duplicate records, improving data accuracy
    • Ensure a cleaner database for operations and sales forecasts

entry.title: Data Attribute Recommendation: 12-Month Support Window for New and Existing Deployments
entry.content:
As of September 1st, 2025,â€¯Data Attribute Recommendationâ€¯will only support the deployment of trained models that are less than 12 months old. Additionally, any existing deployments that are more than 12 months old will be retired automatically, ensuring that only up-to-date, high-quality models remain active. 

 

Why is this change being introduced?  

The overall goal is to strengthen the security and enhance the machine learning lifecycle of the service. To achieve this, we recommend that you, as a user of Data Attribute Recommendation, retrain and redeploy your models on a regular basis. This brings numerous benefits, including the following:  

  • Security: Keeping all your deployments up to date makes sure that they constantly benefit from the security patches and fixes delivered with every release of the service. 
  • Data Drift: Over time, the statistical properties of the data received by the model may change. This phenomenon is known as data drift and can cause the model's performance to degrade. Regular retraining helps the model adapt to these data changes. 
  • Concept Drift: This is similar to data drift, but instead of the data changing, the relationship between the input data and the target variable(s) changes. Regular retraining helps the model capture these new relationships. 
  • Improved Data Availability: Over time, more data usually becomes available. Training a new model with this additional data can improve its accuracy and robustness. 
  • Model Improvements: Machine learning is a rapidly evolving field where new algorithms, architectures, and techniques are constantly being developed. Performance, efficiency, and scalability improvements are regularly included in the Data Attribute Recommendation scenarios. Therefore, retraining regularly allows you to take full advantage of these continuous enhancements. 
  • Error Correction: Regular retraining allows you to correct any errors or biases that were present in the initial training data or model.  

Retraining and redeploying models on a regular basis is a best practice that ensures your machine learning systems remain robust, relevant, and aligned with your organizationâ€™s strategic goals and operational requirements.  

 

How to keep your models up to date in Data Attribute Recommendation  

  • Ensure the latest data is uploaded to the service. 
  • Train a new model on the data: If you want to do this while the old model is still running, you must choose a different model name.  
  • Deploy the newly trained model. 
  • Update the URL that you send your inference requests to. They should now go to the newly trained model. 
  • Undeploy the old model. 

 To complete these steps, we recommend that you consult our documentation: AI API Reference.

What Is SAP Business AI?

Welcome back to our new blog series,  our previous blog series  delved into the intricacies of dynamic sequential approval workflows.

In this two-part series, my colleague @Adwait_Fadnavis  and I will explore some very critical business workflow  requirements  in detail using SAP Build Process Automation. 

Throughout this blog series, we will delve into the following critical business requirements:

Part 1 - Current Blog :Mastering Complex SBPA Approvals : A Deep Dive into Wait Steps, Script Tasks, and API Integrations

Part 2 : Demonstration with Complete end to end testing 

We will demonstrate how to use various SAP Build Process Automation tools to solve real-time challenges effectively.

This blog post addresses this complex requirement with detailed step-by-step instructions. You'll learn how to ensure workflows advance smoothly, even with  approval condition utilizing various innovative latest features such as: Wait Step with API Triggering , Workflow Context update via API etc.

Business Context and Problem Statement

While working on multiple SAP Build Process Automation projects, we have faced situations where workflows only proceed if all departments or approvers approve them unanimously.

If any approver rejects the proposal, the entire workflow is rejected . This creates a need for a parallel approval process, adhering to an "all-or-nothing" requirement, which SAP's standard solutions do not support.

In a below sample procurement workflow, the request is created and submitted. Both the Department Manager and Finance Department must approve it simultaneously. If either rejects, the workflow is terminated.

If both approve, the request goes to the Executive for final approval. The Executive's decision determines whether the request is processed or terminated.

Dynamic Number of Parallel Approval
Technical Solutioning & Design

In this process, we will create two workflows using SAP Build Process Automationâ€™s Low Code/No Code approach.

Letâ€™s refer to these as Workflow A (main workflow) and Workflow B.

Workflow A( Main Workflow): This is the main workflow, triggered with all input parameters, responsible for the overall business process flow.

Workflow B(Secondary Workflow): This workflow handles the approval task. It receives the Approval ID, total number of levels, and current level. If the final approval is granted, it triggers a wait step API  in Workflow A to proceed to the next level. If more approvals are needed, it sends the Approval ID to the next level.

 
Technical Design Steps for Workflow A:
 
  1. Trigger Workflow: The workflow is initiated with input parameters.
  2. Decision Creation: A decision step is created to determine the number of approvals require.

Technical Design Steps for Workflow B  (Triggered via Workflow A)

  1. Trigger from Workflow A : Workflow B starts when Workflow A reaches a certain point to manage approval tasks separately and in parallel to the main workflow.

  2. Send Approval Task: The approval task is sent to the current level approver to obtain necessary approvals at each level before proceeding.

entry.title: Multi-modal RAG Proof of Concept: facilitating tech support
entry.content:
Disclaimer

Please keep an eye on the current state of SAPâ€™s Grounding service, as it will receive updates implementing Multi-modal RAG features in the future. For the extraction of structured data only, you might also want to consider using SAPâ€™s Document Information Extraction service.

Introduction

As the applicability of generative AI in different use cases is being tested and researched every day at SAP, many new approaches are implemented to be proven possible and reliable. While Retrieval Augmented Generation (RAG) is less of a new topic in this context, its utility remains highly variable, depending on the data types that the respective documents contain.

This blog outlines how a multi-modal RAG approach was successfully implemented as part of a proof-of-concept (PoC) for one of SAPâ€™s customers, therefore fulfilling the reoccurring customer need for an AI assistant with the ability to interpret image content. We will focus on how the multi-modal RAG works, as itâ€™s leveraging several SAP services, just as custom-built approaches.

Business situation & challenge

To begin with, we will look at the business situation and the resulting challenges at hand. In this case, an insurance company faced the challenge of handling a high volume of repetitive requests from business users concerning various systems and applications, with differing levels of complexity and detail. The company operates an implementation of one of SAPâ€™s standard LoB solutions, enhanced by its own custom extensions. These extensions are thoroughly documented, using text, graphics, and diagrams to convey key information. However, the IT support team continues to struggle with overload and availability issues, as users often submit questions directly rather than consulting the available manuals. Additionally, similar business requests are repeatedly submitted by different business users and handled separately by various IT team members. This fragmented approach leads to significant inefficiencies and contributes to the IT teamâ€™s overload. Looking at these challenges, we saw the potential for an AI solution to enhance the efficiency of business support and consulting.

Implemented solution

To realize this potential, we developed an AI-driven partner for instant support, relieving a lot of the IT teamâ€™s workload by answering said business requests.

As mentioned in the beginning of this blog, this project was executed as a PoC, exploring a solution that efficiently manages recurring business requests by leveraging AI capabilities. This involves a web application on the SAP Business Technology Platform (SAP BTP), utilizing technologies such as the Generative AI Hub in SAP AI Core and SAP HANA Cloudâ€™s Vector Engine to provide enriched support content and timely responses, ultimately alleviating IT strain and enhancing service availability. Responses are based on the extension manuals, which include both text and images that need to be interpreted to generate reliable answers. While plain text and tables are easily retrievable and result in (...mostly ^^) reliable answers, pictures, diagrams and dashboards present a challenge when trying to generate document-based responses â€“ this is where the multi-modal RAG comes into play. To clarify the scope of our solution, it should be stated that we did not implement functionality for detecting or processing tables, as tables were not part of the provided documents.

Technical Architecture

Before we dive into the workflow of our multi-modal RAG solution, letâ€™s take a quick look at the Architecture of the web application which implements the RAG Reference Architecture on SAP Architecture Center.


The web application is built on SAP BTP, running on its Cloud Foundry Runtime, thereby ensuring scalability and managed infrastructure. We used the SAP Cloud Application Programming Model (CAP) to develop the backend services and Use Case Logic, utilizing LLM Plugins, SDKs and the SAP Cloud SDK for AI which are important for our multi-modal RAG purposes. The CAP application accesses the Generative AI Hub in SAP AI Core via Generative AI Hub SDK, harnessing Generative AI capabilities in a model-agnostic way. In our case, we use gpt-4o which acts as an agent and is one of two nodes in a simple langgraph, the other node being used to invoke our agent tools. Speaking of multiple tools here is not accurate though, as we exclusively invoke our multi-modal RAG as a tool for the agent to access. Having an agent only using a single tool might seem absurd but it turns out that for some rather complex questions, the agent will still break things down into multiple invocations of the same tool (with different queries) and then combine the answers together in a final step. â€“ we will go into the further details of that when talking about the multi-modal RAG approach in a moment. Frontend wise, UI5 Web Components was used to build the User Interface, which we deploy at a HTML5 App Repo.

Multi-modal RAG

Now that we have outlined the overall application architecture, letâ€™s get to the interesting part! Keep in mind that one of the main challenges we are faced with is interpreting the images contained in our documents to retrieve all the relevant information when necessary.

When designing a multi-modal RAG pipeline, one must evaluate and choose among several approaches. As shown in this GitHub Repository published by LangChain, we saw three possible options on how to build our RAG pipeline. While the LangChain documentation provides a general overview of how to implement this approach, we will delve deeper into the specifics of our solution to highlight technical details and differences to the LangChain approach:



As you can see, we do a lot of preprocessing for the documents before putting them in our database to fetch them at runtime. Naturally, we will first take a look at whatâ€™s happening at design time.

First, all the images contained in the pdfs are extracted using the python fitz library. The images are then fed to the LLM, which is instructed to generate descriptions of said images (as explained earlier, the LLM access happens via Generative AI Hub SDK). In a subsequent step, the images in the documents are replaced with their generated description and a reference to the image itself. Ultimately, the plain text - containing image descriptions and references â€“ is chunked with LangChainâ€™s semantic chunker and embedded using text-embedding-ada-002, which is consumed via Generative AI Hub SDK. Those embeddings are stored together with the original text and images in HANA Cloudâ€™s Vector storage.

At runtime, every user query is embedded (again, using text-embedding-ada002). The Vector Engine performs a similarity search on the stored document embeddings, compares them to the embedded user query and picks the ten most similar chunks, just as the next chunk in front of and behind each of them. Since LLMs have a limit on the number of images they can accept as input, we must overcome this limitation when the context to be provided to the LLM includes more images than supported. We do so by passing in image descriptions for the extra images (coming from chunks with lesser relevance) instead of their actual image data. As depicted in the multi-modal RAG diagram above, the stored original text for each chunk is then, together with all the base64-encoded image data and potential image descriptions, given to the LLM for it to generate an answer. That way we can ensure that the LLM includes relevant information contained in the images just as reliably as if we retrieved text only. In other words: the LLM doesn't usually rely on image descriptions as its main source of information. That only tends to happen when the number of images exceeds the modelâ€™s processing limits. Typically, the input includes both the stored text and base64-encoded images within each chunk. 

Conclusion

We hope that this blog has given you a better understanding of how a custom-built multi-modal RAG application can look like. With our PoC we aim to take a step towards increased AI utility, exploring and enhancing existing techniques of combined text and image retrieval to set ground for future projects and upcoming SAP services. Implementing this solution enables users to interact with complex, document-based content in a natural way by combining text and visual information to generate context-aware, AI-powered answers that go beyond traditional RAG usage.

Looking forward to future research on new ways of implementing and enhancing multi-modal RAG, we invite you to ask questions and discuss on this topic in the comment section of this blog. Glad we got you hooked until the end! ğŸ˜‰

Finally, a big thank you to the entire team â€“ @adi_pleyer, @kay, Vikas Thimmiaha, @Jackson7, @RobinP, @GerdBuchmueller,   @andriysobolsap, @g_kevorkian  and @ababalau - for your outstanding work and collaboration throughout this PoC.

entry.title: â€œThe Unfiltered Truth About AI in SAP SuccessFactors: Insights and Realities
entry.content:
SAP SuccessFactors continues to embed AI capabilities across its key modules- Performance & Goals Management, Succession & Development Planning, and Talent Intelligence Hub, aiming to improve HR efficiency and decision-making. However, alongside these promising functionalities, real-world usage reveals notable challenges and limitations HR leaders must consider.

Note: Based on my expertise, this blog mentions AI functionalities in only a few SAP SuccessFactors modulesâ€”PMGM, SPCDP, and TIH.

AI in Performance & Goals Management (PMGM): Efficiency Meets Alignment

The latest AI-driven innovation in PMGM includes generative AI that helps draft personalized, aligned employee goals quickly, reducing administrative workload. Additionally, AI analyzes continuous feedback and performance data to provide managers with insights into employee trends and development needs.

The Reality Check: PMGM's AI Goal Creation

  • Week 1: Users are amazed by the speed

  • Week 2: Managers notice that AI-generated goals sound similar across teams; goals feel â€œrobotic.â€

  • Week 3:  Few AI-created goals are technically correct but practically purposeless, and most goals do not align with organizational strategy. As a result, Managers and HR spend time editing AI-generated goals instead of creating them

The Consultantâ€™s Fix

AI-generated goals often require human review to ensure relevance and alignment with team dynamics. Overreliance on AI can lead to generic or misaligned objectives that fail to motivate employees. Use AI as your first draft, not your final answer. Think of it as having a very efficient intern who still needs supervision.

Succession & Development Planning (SPCDP): Data-Driven Yet Human-Centric

AI in SPCDP supports data-driven succession decisions by assessing potential successors' skills, experience, and readiness. It also recommends personalized career development paths and learning opportunities tailored to individual skill gaps.

The Reality Check

AI confidently recommends a high-performing individual contributor for a leadership role, completely missing the fact that this person had zero interest in management. The AI saw the skills match but it missed the human factor.

The Three Questions AI Canâ€™t Answer (Yet)

  1. Does this person actually want the role? AI sees potential, not passion

  2. How will they handle the pressure? Performance under stress isnâ€™t in the algorithm

  3. Do they fit the team culture? Soft skills remain frustratingly soft for AI.

While AI provides objective successor ratings and development suggestions, these outputs depend heavily on data quality and contextual interpretation by HR professionals. AI recommendations can miss cultural fit or individual aspirations if treated as prescriptive rather than advisory. Organizations must balance AI insights with human judgment to avoid rigid or ineffective succession plans.

The Consultantâ€™s Fix

Use AI insights as your starting point for conversations, not your end point for decisions. The suggestions should guide, but not replace, human decisions. Career insights work better for junior roles than senior positions. Career insights help plan learning paths, but they must align with company culture and employee goals to be effective.

Talent Intelligence Hub (TIH): Precision in Skills Management

TIHâ€™s AI now focuses on recent job roles to keep skills data accurate. It recommends learning based on skill levels and improves team visibility for managers. AI-driven learning suggestions help employees focus their development. Workflow updates add control over skill approvals, helping maintain clean data. This holistic view, powered by AI, helps organizations not only fill current roles but also anticipate future workforce trends and succession risks.

The Reality Check

TIHâ€™s AI is like having a very enthusiastic research assistant who finds exactly what you asked for, even when itâ€™s not what you need.

For TIH, the foundational requirement for clean, structured data is a major barrier. Many organizations find their HR data inconsistent or disconnected, limiting AI effectiveness. Without significant data cleanup, AI-driven insights in TIH may be inaccurate or misleading.

  • AI extracts every possible skill from job descriptions, creating overly large skill inventories that are difficult to manage.

  • AI suggests learning content for every skill gap, regardless of priority or relevance.

The Consultantâ€™s Fix

  • Skills extraction works best for technical roles with clear competency requirements.

  • Learning recommendations are most effective for certification-based skills.

  • Ethical concerns around AI bias and transparency require ongoing governance and monitoring to maintain trust.

Strategic Takeaways for HR Leaders

  • Use AI to automate tasks, but always apply human judgment.

  • Keep data clean and governed for reliable AI results.

  • Set clear, realistic goals for AI adoption.

Conclusion

AI in HR isnâ€™t about replacing human judgment; itâ€™s about giving humans better data to make judgment calls. When you approach it that way, the technology becomes genuinely helpful rather than frustratingly inaccurate.

The future of HR technology isnâ€™t about perfect AIâ€”itâ€™s about perfectly integrated AI that knows its place in human-centered processes.

If you want to explore how to balance AI and human insight in your HR processes, feel free to reach out for guidance.

Thank you for taking the time to read.

You are welcome to express your views and ask any queries in the comment section of this blog. I would be pleased to impart my knowledge to you.  Share this blog with your colleagues.

Additional Blogs

If you are planning a  Talent Intelligence Hub implementation, this blog has all the practical insights I've gained from actually deploying TIH in real client environments - the stuff that matters when you're in the middle of an implementation and need straight answers. TIH Implementation: Key Learnings from Client Projects

entry.title: Shaping the Future of Predictive Insights with Tabular AI and the SAP Foundational Model
entry.content:
Abstract

At SAP Sapphire, we unveiled a major milestone in our ongoing mission to simplify and elevate AI capabilities for our customers: Tabular AI. This groundbreaking initiative consolidates all of SAPâ€™s existing AI services for structured tabular business data into a single, unified offering within SAPâ€™s Generative AI Hub. Scheduled for general availability in the second half of 2025, tabular AI will streamline integration, enhance accessibility, and dramatically reduce complexity for developers and business users alike.

Beyond unification, tabular AI is designed as a launchpad for rapid innovationâ€”setting the stage for next-generation capabilities like the SAP Foundation Model. Initially, these foundation model features will be available for embedded use cases, with a vision to expand to custom scenarios in the future, giving customers even greater flexibility.

If youâ€™re new to the SAP Foundation Model we encourage you to explore our dedicated blog post and the on-demand SAP TechEd session for a comprehensive introduction. These resources provide valuable context on how foundational AI technologies are reshaping business applications.

Tabular AI underscores SAPâ€™s commitment to democratizing AI and empowering every customer to unlock value from their data. Discover more in the full blog post and get ready for the future of enterprise AI.

 

The Challenge

Letâ€™s start by facing the current reality. Business processes in enterprises heavily rely on structured tabular data. When it comes to creating predictive insights from this data, our landscape today is fragmented and siloed. While SAP has developed robust AI services tailored for structured tabular data, such as Data Attribute Recommendation for classification and regression scenarios, Personalized Recommendations delivering tailored user experiences and relevant content to support diverse business objectives and recommendation scenarios., and embedded matching scenarios (like Cash Application), each solving specific challenges effectively, these services would benefit by harmonizing into a comprehensive, unified solution for customers.

This structure has evolved naturally over time, resulting in each AI service possessing its distinct architecture and workflow. While these services are functional, SAP is actively enhancing them to streamline integration and simplify adoption for application developers. These ongoing improvements also pave the way for more rapid and seamless incorporation of cutting-edge innovations, such as the SAP Foundation Model, across our AI Services landscape.

We are excited to announce the introduction of tabular AI, a significant step forward in advancing our AI capabilities. Tabular AI will serve two key objectives: first, to unify our existing AI services tailored for structured tabular data into a single, integrated platform, and second, to expedite the integration of groundbreaking AI research, particularly in the realm of generative AI, into our products. This strategic move is aimed at not only simplifying the technological landscape but also at propelling our offerings to the forefront of AI innovation.

 

Unification

Tabular AI will unify all existing AI service offerings for structured tabular data under the umbrella of SAPâ€™s Generative AI Hub, streamlining integration, lifecycle management, and accelerating implementation timelines. This comprehensive approach will democratize predictive AI capabilities, making them more accessible and easier to maintain. By doing so, business developers will be better equipped to effectively leverage these tools within their custom AI applications or embedded AI scenarios. As a result, business developers will be better equipped to leverage these tools in custom AI applications and embedded AI scenarios. For application developers, this unification means a simpler integration process, with a single service plan and service key required for their applications.

With this transformative change, the focus shifts from selecting a suitable AI solution for an application to concentrating directly on the desired AI functionality - be it classification, regression, matching, recommendation, or other capabilities that may emerge in the future. Notably, the inclusion of the matching capability represents a significant enhancement, as this functionality was not previously available through an existing AI service offering.

Moving forward, all these functionalities will be accessible through a unified entry point - the AI API. This consolidation simplifies the user experience and expedites the deployment of advanced AI capabilities, allowing developers to seamlessly integrate and apply these functionalities across various applications more efficiently without the challenges of managing multiple technologies or models. By eliminating barriers related to the technology stack and model selection, developers can more effectively concentrate on utilizing the precise functionality needed to add value in their specific contexts, thereby driving innovative use of AI across industries.

However, tabular AI isn't just about simplifying the developer's experience; it also paves the way for seamless integration of future innovations. A prominent example is the SAP Foundation Model, leading us into the discussion of innovation.

 

Innovation

With tabular AI in place, we are seizing the opportunity to stay at the forefront of innovation. By unifying our architecture and workflow, Tabular AI enables the seamless integration of cutting-edge technologies and native adoption of new advancements.

At launch, tabular AI will incorporate advanced AI models designed to deliver unprecedented levels of predictive insight and flexibility. Leveraging large-scale business data, these models will unlock a wealth of new use cases and transform the way users interact with our solutions.

A key feature is the SAP Foundation Model, a table-native Transformer that brings adaptive, in-context learning to tabular AI. Unlike traditional models that require repeated training for each use case, the SAP Foundation Model provides on-the-fly predictions for individual records based on provided examples. This adaptability allows the model to respond dynamically to changing data without retraining, substantially simplifying the entire machine learning lifecycle and reducing operational complexity.

Customers will benefit from increased intelligence and automation in embedded scenarios, enabling faster, more accurate decision-making. Over time, this technology will supercharge a broad range of use cases across the SAP portfolio - streamlining business processes, increasing efficiency, and reducing manual effort.

Initially, this capability will support embedded classification and regression use cases within SAP applications. This focused rollout ensures high reliability while setting the stage for expanding to broader custom scenarios in the future.

 

What's in for Me

Looking ahead to 2025, our vision is to make AI for structured data both simpler and more powerful for everyone using SAP. With the upcoming launch of tabular AI as a flagship service within SAPâ€™s Generative AI Hub, we are unifying and streamlining all our existing capabilities by consolidating features from Data Attribute Recommendation and Personalized Recommendation and introducing matching as a native capability. As your business data evolves, the model dynamically adapts, delivering relevant predictions and keeping pace with changing requirements

For the initial release of those advanced capabilities powered by the SAP Foundation Model, we are prioritizing embedded scenarios such as classification and regression tasks deeply integrated within SAP applications. By focusing on well-established use cases with proven business value, we can rigorously test and refine in-context learning, ensuring maximum reliability and robustness. This strategy will help us build a strong foundation for expanding advanced capabilities to broader and more customized scenarios in the future.

All of this is, however, just the beginning. Looking ahead, we anticipate a transformational leap in how advanced AI models generate insights from linked business data. These developments will also pave the way for the next generation of highly autonomous, agentic AI scenarios. Unlike todayâ€™s narrow AI models, future scenarios will support a broader range of execution and will benefit from precisely grounded insights, leveraging the foundation of structured tabular data for greater accuracy and reliability.

In effect, we expect nothing less than a democratization of AI in the structured tabular space, where a massive growth of capabilities is fueled by empowering application developers and end users alike to generate targeted AI insights as easily and swiftly as writing prompts for textual tasks performed by an LLM. As these capabilities advance, generating insights with AI will become standard practice rather than an exception - until, eventually, almost every process will be AI-powered, with only a few remaining untouched.

As part of this evolution, we will begin to phase out and deprecate our legacy AI services. This move will fully realize the unification vision: A single, universal entry point for all AI capabilities supporting structured business data. Unifying our services brings several strategic benefits:

Conclusion

Tabular AI marks a significant leap towards simplifying and unifying AI for structured business data at SAP. While the initial focus is on embedded use cases, our long-term vision is a flexible, unified offering that adapts to evolving business needs and fosters innovation at scale. entry.title: Using Trading Partner Management with AI
entry.content:
Extending AI Capabilities: Diving Deeper with the MCP Trading Partner Management Server

Following up on my previous article, "Using Integration Suite with the Power of AI," where I showcased how to extend Integration Suite development with AI and the ModelContextProtocol (MCP), I'm excited to introduce a specialized enhancement: the **MCP Trading Partner Management (TPM) Server**.

While the initial MCP Integration Suite Server provides broad tools for general CPI functions like Integration Flows and Message Mappings, many enterprise integration scenarios heavily rely on managing B2B relationships. This new server is purpose-built to give AI chat clients direct access to and control over the rich capabilities of SAP Integration Suite's Trading Partner Management. It makes sense to install both servers together to have access to both tools combined.

 

What Can You Do With It? A Comprehensive Toolset

The MCP Trading Partner Management Server empowers AI assistants with a wide array of tools to manage your B2B integration aspects. Here's an overview of its core capabilities:

  • Trading Partner Management: Create, retrieve, and manage trading partners, their systems, identifiers, communication channels, and even signature verification configurations.
  • Agreement Management: Work with B2B agreements, including creation from templates, retrieving details, and managing their associated technical B2B scenarios and deployments.
  • Message Implementation Guideline (MIG) Management: Access and manipulate MIGs, including inspecting nodes and fields, applying proposals, and creating new MIG drafts.
  • Mapping Guideline (MAG) Management: Create mapping guidelines and test them with example data
  • Monitoring: Search for interchanges, retrieve payload data, download specific payloads, and access error details for TPM message monitoring.
  • Other Utilities: Get details on type systems, messages within them, create custom messages, and retrieve master data like business process roles, countries, and product classifications.

 

Setup and Configuration

As with the previous server, I highly recommend using this tool with Cline, the VSCode extension, or any other MCP-compatible client.

This server requires **Java (version 17 or higher)** and **Gradle (version 8 or higher)** to be installed on your machine. Once you have these prerequisites, get started by cloning the project and building it:

git clone https://github.com/1nbuc/mcp-is-tpm.git
cd mcp-is-tpm
./gradlew build

Next, you'll need to add the MCP Trading Partner Management Server to your AI Client's MCP configuration. This is typically done alongside your existing `mcp-is` configuration to provide the full spectrum of tools. The `env` variables below should be configured with your SAP Integration Suite URL and user credentials.

Note on Credentials: If your S or P user is associated with a Universal ID, ensure you provide your Universal ID password and email (`CPI_UNIVERSAL_MAIL`). If you have a standalone S-User, simply omit the `CPI_UNIVERSAL_MAIL` variable.

{
  "mcpServers": {
    "mcp-is": {
      "command": "node",
      "args": [
        "<project path for mcp-integration-suite>/dist/index.js"
      ],
      "autoApprove": []
    },
    "mcp-is-tpm": {
      "command": "java",
      "args": [
        "-Dlogging.pattern.console=",
        "-Dspring.main.web-application-type=none",
        "-Dspring.ai.mcp.server.stdio=true",
        "-jar",
        "<project path for mcp-is-tpm>/app/build/libs/app-0.0.1-SNAPSHOT.jar"
      ],
      "autoApprove": [],
      "env": {
        "CPI_URL": "https://your.cpi.url.hana.ondemand.com",
        "CPI_USER": "S001234567",
        "CPI_PASSWORD": "myPass123",
        "CPI_UNIVERSAL_MAIL": "mail@company.de"
      }
    }
  }
}

Remember to replace `<project path for mcp-integration-suite>` and `<project path for mcp-is-tpm>` with the actual local paths to your cloned repositories.

For optimal interaction and to guide the AI effectively, I highly recommend starting each chat session with a custom prompt, similar to the approach outlined in my previous blog post.

 

What Can You Actually Do With It? (Conceptual Examples)

With the comprehensive toolset provided by the MCP Trading Partner Management Server, you can instruct your AI assistant to handle intricate TPM tasks. Here are a few conceptual examples:

Example 1: Create new Partners and Communication with them

You are a fishing shop with SAP ERP and SAP Integration suite
Here is a list of trading partners, look if they exist already otherwise create them.
Rod Supplier rody
Fishermans port LLC

Here is a list of transactions I do with partners. For every partnertransaction find a suitable Agreement template and create an agreement based on it.
All partners use AS2. If there is no fitting System with communication please create it. Deploy the agreements afterwards
Send orders D01B to rody
Receive D01B invoices from rody
Send TRADACOMS invoices to fishermans port

This could also be done if a list of 100+ User is provided e.g. if you would have an excel sheet with some partners and want to save time by not having to click create such many times.

 

Example 2: Analyzing an Existing Trading Partner Configuration

"Get details about Partner XY and list all their configured systems and communication channels."

This is also usefull for summerizing or finding stuff.

"Find all Partners that use a SOAP Channel"

Example 3: Creating a New MIG for an Inbound PO

"Create a new Message Implementation Guideline for an inbound Purchase Order (PO) based on the EDIFACT D.96A standard. Then, get the proposal and select all fields which have over 50% probability."

This highlights the ability to automate the creation of structured message guidelines, which are foundational for B2B document exchange.

Example 4: Troubleshooting an Inbound B2B Message

"Search for all interchanges with errors in the last day from partner 'XYSolutions'. For the latest error message, get the interchange payloads and identify the root cause from the last error details."

This scenario leverages the monitoring tools to quickly pinpoint and diagnose issues in B2B message processing.

 

 

If you are interested do not hesitate to check out the project on github for more details. I look forward to hearing your thoughts and experiences in the comments, also let me know if you have any features or promps you would like to see! Also thanks to figaf for providing an API for lots of TPM Capabilities.

entry.title: Using the SAP Cloud Javascript SDK for AI
entry.content:
Using the SAP Cloud Javascript SDK for AI

Introduction

In this blog, We will build a Node.js Service with authenticaton that Talks to SAP Generative AI Hub. Weâ€™ll spin up a tiny Express server, protect it with XSUAA, call an OpenAI model (gpt-4o-mini) deployed in the Generative AI Hub, and push the whole thing to Cloud Foundry.

Source code is ~70 lines; everything else is service wiring.

Table of Contents

  1. Prerequisites
  1. Step 1 â€” Destination services
  1. Step 2 â€” Create the XSUAA instance
  1. Step 3 â€” Scaffold the Node project
  1. Step 4 â€” Deploy to BTP
  1. Step 5 â€” Test with Postman
  1. Useful Links

1 Â· Prerequisites

  • BTP sub-account (any region)
  • Generative AI Hub enabled in BTP Cockpit
  • Node.js â‰¥ 18 & cf CLI v8 - https://nodejs.org
  • Postman - https://www.postman.com/
  • VSCode - https://code.visualstudio.com/
  • AI Core Instance & Service Key created from BTP

2 Â· Step 1 â€” Create Destination Service

Creation of a Destination Service is needed as we will be using it to connect to our GenAI hub instance. There is a way to define custom destination programatically mentioned here.

https://sap.github.io/cloud-sdk/docs/js/features/connectivity/destinations#register-destination

However from my testing I just couldnâ€™t got it to connect to my genai instance. So I will be creating a destination following the documentation

https://sap.github.io/ai-sdk/docs/js/connecting-to-ai-core

  1. Create the Destination Service

    Go to the Instances and Subscriptions and click the create button to the right

Select the Destination Service and name it whatever you like

Click on the newly created Destination Service Instance and create a Service Key for it

And then click the 3 dots up on the right corner and go to option View Dashboard here we will be creating a destination. Create a HTTP destination and select Authentication type as â€œOAuth2ClientCredentialsâ€ paste-in the values you have beforehand from the AI Core Service service key.

Important!

Make sure to add /oauht/token to the end of your Token Service URL if there is none.

Click Check Connection. It will give a message;

âœ…Connection to "my-aicore" established. Response returned: "404: Not Foundâ€.

This is fine as we are not sending a request to the destination yet.

3 Â· Step 2 â€” Create XSUAA Service and Service Key

Just like the steps we did when creating our Destination Service create an Authorization and Trust Management (XSUAA) service instance and then create a service key for it.

Only thing to pay attention is to select plan â€œbrokerâ€ when creating the service

Then just create the service keys for this service aswell.

4 Â· Step 3 â€” Scaffold the Node project

mkdir genai-node && cd genai-node
npm init -y
npm i express -ai-sdk/foundation-models
npm i cfenv /xssec
npm i -D typescript rimraf
npm i -D @types/express @types/cfenv to the
npx tsc --init --outDir dist --rootDir src \
 --target es2022 --module es2022 \
 --moduleResolution node --esModuleInterop tru
mkdir src
touch .cfignore #here put the paths of the files you don't want to deploy to BTP
âš ï¸TypeScript typings & Express version
  • This tutorial uses express@5.1 (bundles its own .d.ts files).

    Do not install @types/express with Express 5 â€“ VS Code will show

    â€œDuplicate identifier / Cannot redeclare â€¦â€ errors because two sets of
    typings clash.

  • If you decide to downgrade to express@4.x, then you must add

    npm i -D @types/express so the compiler can find the declarations.

In both cases you can safely install the helpers below:

# always safe
npm i -D @types/node @types/cfenv

They silence any remaining red squiggles without affecting runtime.

Complete tsconfig.json

{
 "compilerOptions": {
 "target": "es2022",
 "module": "es2022",
 "moduleResolution": "node",
 "rootDir": "src",
 "outDir": "dist",
 "esModuleInterop": true,
 "allowSyntheticDefaultImports": true,
 "skipLibCheck": true // turns off deep type-checking in node_modules
 },
 "include": ["src/**/*.ts", "*.ts"]
}

Complete package.json

{
 "name": "genai-node",
 "version": "1.0.0",
 "type": "module",
 "scripts": {
 "build": "rimraf dist && tsc",
 "start": "npm run build && node dist/server.js"
 },
 "dependencies": {
 "@sap-ai-sdk/ai-api": "^1.15.0",
 "@sap-ai-sdk/foundation-models": "^1.15.0",
 "@sap-ai-sdk/langchain": "^1.15.0",
 "@sap-ai-sdk/orchestration": "^1.15.0",
 "@sap-cloud-sdk/connectivity": "^4.0.2",
 "@sap/xssec": "^4.8.0",
 "cfenv": "^1.2.4",
 "dotenv": "^16.5.0",
 "express": "^5.1.0"
 },
 "devDependencies": {
 "rimraf": "^6.0.1",
 "ts-node": "^10.9.2",
 "tsx": "^4.20.3",
 "typescript": "^5.8.3"
 }
}

We compile on CF during npm start; the buildpack installs devDeps by default, so no extra steps required.

Create src/server.ts:

import express, { Request, Response, NextFunction } from 'express';
import { AzureOpenAiChatClient } from '@sap-ai-sdk/foundation-models';
import xssec from '@sap/xssec';
import cfenv from 'cfenv';
const app = express();
const port = process.env.PORT || 3000;
const XSUAA_SERVICE_NAME = process.env.XSUAA_SERVICE_NAME;
const appEnv = cfenv.getAppEnv();
const xsuaaService = appEnv.getService(XSUAA_SERVICE_NAME as any);
if (!xsuaaService) {
 throw new Error(`XSUAA service "${XSUAA_SERVICE_NAME}" not bound!`);
}
const uaaCreds = xsuaaService.credentials;
function verifyJwt(req: Request, _res: Response, next: NextFunction) {
 const auth = req.headers.authorization;
 if (!auth?.startsWith('Bearer ')) {
 return _res.status(403).send('Missing bearer token');
 }
 const token = auth.slice(7);
 xssec.createSecurityContext(token, uaaCreds)
 .then(() => next())
.catch((e: any) => {
 console.error('JWT rejected â†’', e.innerError ?? e.message ?? e);
 _res.status(403).send(String(e.innerError?.message ?? e.message));
});
}
const chat = new AzureOpenAiChatClient(
 {
 modelName: 'gpt-4o-mini' ,
 resourceGroup: 'your-resource-group'
 },
 {
 destinationName: 'my-aicore'
 }
);
app.post('/chat', verifyJwt express.json(), async (req, res) => {
 const userMsg = String(req.body.message ?? '');
 try {
 const resp = await chat.run({
 messages: [{ role: 'user', content: userMsg }]
 });
 res.json({ answer: resp.getContent() });
 } catch (e: any) {
 console.error(e);
 res.status(500).json({ error: e?.message ?? 'server error' });
 }
});
app.listen(port, () => console.log('â‡¢ listening on', port));

5 Â· Step 4 â€” Deploy to BTP

manifest.yaml

---
applications:
 - name: genai-node
 buildpack: nodejs_buildpack
 command: npm start
 memory: 256M
 env:
 XSUAA_SERVICE_NAME: xsuaa-blog #Name of your service
 services:
 - destination-service
 - xsuaa-blog

Push the codebase to the CloudFoundry and check if it is running

cf push
cf logs genai-node --recent

5 Â· Step 6â€”Test with Postman

After you deploy the application click on it to get the custom link to the app.

  • Open up Postman and write your request with your endpoint
  • Go to the Authorization tab â†’ Select OAuth 2.0
  • Enter credentials

  • Scroll down to the â€œGet New Access Tokenâ€ and then â€œUse Tokenâ€.

Now you are good to send the request and get a result

{
 "answer": "Hello! How can I assist you today?"
}

7 Â· Useful Links

  • https://www.sap.com/events/teched/virtual/flow/sap/te24/catalog/page/catalog/session/1722557682293001fTqe
  • https://github.com/SAP-samples/teched2024-AI180
  • https://sap.github.io/ai-sdk/docs/js/connecting-to-ai-core
  • https://sap.github.io/cloud-sdk/docs/js/tutorials/getting-started/introduction

entry.title: Exploring SAP Generative AI SDK: Python, JavaScript, and Java Libraries ğŸ
entry.content:
SAP's Generative AI SDK offers powerful tools for integrating AI capabilities into your business applications.

This blog will guide you through the libraries available for Python, JavaScript, and Java, and how to use them effectively.

1.ğŸ”µ SAP Generative AI SDK for Python

The SAP Generative AI SDK for Python allows developers to leverage generative models from the SAP AI Core. This SDK supports models from providers like OpenAI, Amazon, and Google, and integrates with LangChain for enhanced functionality.

Documentation and Examples : https://help.sap.com/doc/generative-ai-hub-sdk/CLOUD/en-US/index.html 

Installation: To install the SDK, use the following command:

pip install sap-ai-sdk-gen[all]

You can also install specific model providers:

pip install "sap-ai-sdk-gen[google, amazon]"

Configuration: Set up your environment variables or configuration file to authenticate and connect to SAP AI Core:

export AICORE_CLIENT_ID="your_client_id"
export AICORE_CLIENT_SECRET="your_client_secret"
export AICORE_AUTH_URL="your_auth_url"
export AICORE_BASE_URL="your_base_url"

Usage: Here's a simple example to generate text using the OpenAI model:

from sap_ai_sdk_gen import OpenAI

client = OpenAI()
response = client.generate_text(prompt="Hello, world!")
print(response)

2.ğŸ”µ SAP Generative AI SDK for JavaScript

The JavaScript SDK enables Node.js applications to interact with SAP AI Core, providing seamless integration with generative models.

https://github.com/SAP/ai-sdk-js 

Installation: Install the SDK via npm:

npm install -ai-sdk/ai-api

Configuration: Ensure your environment variables are set up correctly:

export AICORE_CLIENT_ID="your_client_id"
export AICORE_CLIENT_SECRET="your_client_secret"
export AICORE_AUTH_URL="your_auth_url"
export AICORE_BASE_URL="your_base_url"

Usage: Here's a basic example to generate text:

import { OpenAI } from '@sap-ai-sdk/ai-api';

const client = new OpenAI();
client.generateText('Hello, world!').then(response => {
  console.log(response);
});

3.ğŸ”µ SAP Generative AI SDK for Java

The Java SDK integrates AI capabilities into Java-based applications, leveraging the SAP AI Core's generative models.

https://github.com/SAP/ai-sdk-java

Installation: Add the SDK to your Maven project:

 

<dependency>
  <groupId>com.sap.ai</groupId>
  <artifactId>sap-ai-sdk</artifactId>
  <version>5.6.0</version>
</dependency>

 

Configuration: Configure your application properties:

aicore.client.id=your_client_id
aicore.client.secret=your_client_secret
aicore.auth.url=your_auth_url
aicore.base.url=your_base_url

Usage: Here's an example to generate text:

import com.sap.ai.sdk.OpenAI;

public class Main {
    public static void main(String[] args) {
        OpenAI client = new OpenAI();
        String response = client.generateText("Hello, world!");
        System.out.println(response);
    }
}

Conclusion

SAP's Generative AI SDKs for Python, JavaScript, and Java provide robust tools for integrating AI into your applications. By following the installation, configuration, and usage examples provided, you can start leveraging the power of generative AI in your projects.

Feel free to reach out if you have any questions or need further assistance! Happy coding!
